speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Okay, Mr. Vásquez,

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Okay.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Okay. I'd like to begin by just asking you how it is that you and your family came to the state of Idaho.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Well, when we came to Idaho, it was much. I didn't have a choice. It was something I had to do. I was raised by my grandparents, and at the time we came to Idaho, I was only eight years old, so needless to say, I had to come to the state with my folks to work in the fields.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: So that is how I came to be in Idaho?

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Now you were raised by your grandparents?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I was raised by my grandparents due to the fact that my mother died when I was very young. It was a strange story. I guess it's because when my mother and father separated, I was six months old, my mother took my older brother and raised him until she passed away in 1940.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: But my grandmother took my older sister, Helen, and myself when we were babies, and as little kids, she raised us. So I was raised by my grandmother from early childhood.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: And so, when you were living with your grandparents, where were you living? And if you could explain to me a little bit about how it was that you came to be in Idaho.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: How I came to be in Idaho was, we were living in Grand Junction, Colorado, and we were bean field workers. That's all we knew at the time. So we used to follow the field work. How we came to Idaho: my grandmother had a sister who lived in Salt Lake City, and we went from Grand Junction, Colorado, to Salt Lake City to visit my grandmother's sister.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: And we stayed there maybe six months or a year, I can't really recall how long. And that was in 1937 or '38, I think the fall of 1938. In the fall of 1938, my grandfather and some other people decided to come to Idaho because there was field work to do, sugar beets.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So the opportunity, or...

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Job opportunity arose. And so we came to Preston Idaho, me my grandmother, my sister and my grandfather. We went to Preston Idaho in the fall of 1938.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Did you do any other kind of farm work? Other than beets, did you work in other types of agriculture throughout the years??

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yeah, I remember, when we were little and stayed in Utah, we used to pull onions. I remember topping onions, somewhere close to Salt Lake. But when we came to Idaho, the season was to top beets. It was the fall of the year.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: And so we used to meet and camp. We used a knife with a little hook on the end, like a machete, and that's what we did in 1938. We stayed there all winter of 1938. In the spring of '39, we followed the work.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: So we came to Idaho. Why did we come to Marsing? I'm not really clear whether we knew somebody there or we just happened to say, 'Let’s go to the other part of Idaho, go to Marsing.' But all I know is that we landed in Marsing in 1939. You know, we were here before, they were here.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: They were here.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: When you traveled to Idaho, did you come by your own transportation that year? And did you come out with other families, or was it just your family?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: It was just my grandparents and us. We didn't know anybody. We were just by ourselves. And when we came to Marsing, I think we were by ourselves also.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So you drove?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: We drove here. We had, and I think it was an old pickup truck, if I'm not mistaken. But we landed in Marsing, and the ideal situation in those days was to find a farmer who had year-round work, where you could start in the spring, thin the beets, clean them, and then find some work in between. And then in the fall, you topped the beets. And so that's what we did.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What are your very first memories of Idaho when you first got here? What did you think of it?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Cold, especially in eastern Idaho. It was very, very cold. And, needless to say, working in the fields as a kid, we'd go out to the beet fields, and it was so cold the leaves, the tops from the beets, would break off. They were frozen.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: It was cold.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So do you have any idea where you're from originally?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: No, no, but I like it here. Yeah, it was very cold here.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: I know you said the very first place you came to was Preston.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Can you describe where you lived?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Well, it wasn't long ago, but I'm sure it was just a very small shack, probably just a one-room house that I can remember. We probably had to go to the farmer's house to get water.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: We didn't have any bathroom facilities, you know, you had an outhouse. Okay, so that's what I recall mostly when I first came to Idaho: that it was cold.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Now, once you got here, did you travel to other cities in Idaho or to other states?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Once we came to Idaho, we went to Marsing. We stayed in Marsing and worked in Marsing. But while we were in Marsing, we used to go to other areas, like the McCall-Donnelly area to pick peas. We used to go to Emmett to work in the pea fields.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: And also, we used to grow carrots there, you could tie carrots in the water in the Emmett area. And I also lived temporarily, maybe two or three months, in a labor camp in Oregon.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: And what was that like?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: As a kid, if you have your parents, or your grandparents, you don't put too much emphasis on things like we do now. You don't worry about the economics of it. You just work, go to school, and you've got a place to eat and sleep, and you're happy.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Okay.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So it was positive for you?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Oh, yes, very positive. I remember at that particular time, when we were living in that labor camp, my older brother Rudy got really sick with a constant virus, and he just about died there. But, needless to say, he didn't.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: But so he was hospitalized?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: No, I don't think he was. I think he was just taken care of right there in the camp. He made it through.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Were there any other Mexican American families living in Idaho when you first arrived? Do you remember anything about the Bracero program or undocumented workers?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I remember when they first started to come. As far as other Hispanics being here when we first arrived, I can't recall ever seeing any. I do know that shortly after we came, other Hispanics came to live where we lived in Marsing.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: And I do remember the Braceros, when they used to come here to work in the fields. One of the things that really used to amaze me about those poor people was that they'd work out in the fields like we used to in the wintertime, topping beets, like I was telling you about earlier.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: And they'd wear whatever they had, and, mind you, it was a hard life for them at the time.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What else do you remember from that era about these people who were coming in, like the Braceros?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: The workers, when they first came here, would put up with almost anything to make money to send back to their families in Mexico. They would live in little houses bunched together, shacks all put together.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I do remember when we were living in Marsing in 1940–41, my grandmother used to take in boarders and cook for them. We used to have a little shack in the back, but we lived in a tent, and these people would come to work in the fields. My grandmother made extra money by giving them room and board, and she had to cook for them.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Sometimes there were maybe 12 to 15 people she would board, and she charged them about a dollar to a dollar and a half a day for room and board. She was doing all the cooking for those people on an old wood stove, I'm sure you've seen them. That's how she cooked for all those people.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: You mentioned these people put up with whatever they had to in order to keep working. Do you remember any kind of differential treatment they had to endure?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Well, I can't really say. I don't know if they were treated any differently. At my age, I thought that was just the way it was supposed to be, I thought it was normal. So it's really difficult for me to say they weren't treated fairly, because I didn't know any better.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Do you recall any specific situation?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: No, I don't recall a farmer ever mistreating them or discriminating against them. I cannot recall that. I know they worked hard.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So it sounds like, compared to white workers, they did the same work.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Oh, no, neither did we, really. If we didn't have proper clothing for the conditions, that was our problem. Nobody supplied us with anything.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Was that difficult? Do you remember them having to go out and work without proper clothing?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Again, sometimes we think ignorance is bliss. When you don't know there's something better, you do the best you can with what you have. I'm sure my grandmother and grandfather worried whether we were adequately dressed to do the job, but we didn't know any better.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: And you weren't around any other way of living, so that was normal for you: as long as you had a place to be warm and something to eat.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: So anyway, that's what I remember about growing up as a little Mexican boy here in Marsing.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: When you worked in the fields, do you remember anything about wages, what you were paid?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Well, we always worked piecework, we never got paid by the hour. My grandfather always taught us, 'You're going to get paid for what you do, the more you do, the more you make.' We never worked by the hour. All piecework. I remember topping beets for six or seven dollars an acre.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I remember popping beets by the ton, I can't recall how much per ton, but we used to haul the tops by hand onto a truck. Sometimes the fields were so muddy we had to hitch a team of horses to the truck to pull it out because the weather was so bad. Those little things stick in my mind because they don't happen anymore.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So work was basically just a lot harder than it is today?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Oh yes, right.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: I mean, you were only like ten or twelve years old.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: And I have a grandson who's having a birthday today, he's nine years old. I sit down sometimes, didn't tell him, but I think: at eight years old, I was outside in cold weather, working alongside my grandpa topping beets. And today, we don't even think about it.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yeah

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Right. Now on the subject of education, you did attend school in Marsing. Describe your earliest memory of school.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I started school in Grand Junction, Colorado, in first and second grade. We lived in a place called La Colonia, next to a sugar beet factory, the railroad tracks, and the river, a typical place where they put all the Hispanics.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I think even today we sometimes segregate ourselves, not because Anglo people separate us, but because we do it ourselves. Anyway, I remember walking to school barefoot, we didn't have money sometimes. I started school in Grand Junction up to second grade, and I started third grade in Marsing.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Was there a difference? Did the school system feel different from Colorado to Idaho?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: No, I don't think it was that different. At that time, school was about learning to read, write, and do arithmetic, the 'three R's.' That was most important. We didn't have all the extras we have today, but I didn't notice a real difference. In Colorado or Idaho, you learned to read, write, and do arithmetic.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Right, school must have been nice for you. I know from my own experience that sometimes where I was raised, it was so cold I didn't have enough to keep me warm. You were one of many children, so going to school, a warm room, new pencils, Crayolas, a well-groomed teacher with polish and lipstick, was a whole new world you didn't have at home.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Oh yes, right.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Because of your living conditions, school was like an escape, something nice and orderly.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Well-groomed.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Teachers like that, our mothers weren't glamorous; they were busy raising children, and our fathers were out in the fields. So school was a completely different world.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: It's a completely different world.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Do you recall any other Hispanic children in your class when you came in third grade?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I was the only one, well, me and my sister were the only ones in Marsing until 1940. We were the only Hispanics.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Probably one of the very first.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: First, right.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: First year in this area.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Right, the first Hispanics I can remember. Then in 1940, some other people came from Grand Junction, and I remember them coming to live in Marsing. So it was just me and my sister who were the first Hispanics.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Came here to set up to ah...

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Maravilla, yeah they were there.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: How do you recall being in school as far as grades?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I was just an average student. My parents didn't put much emphasis on education, they figured they'd rather have a good worker than a good scholar. But we did fairly well. I never flunked a grade. The ironic thing is, we used to start school late, like in November, and only go about six months a year because we had to quit early to work in the fields and start late because harvest was still going.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: So my teachers took extra time with me, helping me catch up. And the other kids, the Anglo kids, also helped me. All the teachers were really nice to me and my sister, and the students were very helpful.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: You started in November, it sounded like it was just you. Was that the norm for migrant families?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: School was always September to whenever, but we had to quit and start late because September and October had the best working weather. When it got cold, we went to school all winter. Then in spring, when it warmed up, our parents pulled us out to work. That's why I never flunked, I must have had good teachers who worked hard to help me catch up.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: He was a bright boy, from what I can see. Even when I met him before we got married, I saw so much potential. He's a born mathematician. After we married, he told me that as a little boy, the older men, who couldn't read or write, would single him out to figure out their acreage and pay. He had to be a smart kid to do that.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So your experience was shaped by the harvest, you had to leave school early.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: You know.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: It doesn't sound like you had to move to new cities or states often, so you didn't change schools much.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I remember the only time I changed schools was when we came to Nampa. I started seventh grade there in 1943.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What do you remember about being a Mexican-American student in school?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Being the only one, I didn't think it was any different. I played with the Anglo kids, we fit right in. I never felt out of place.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: You spoke Spanish at home and English in school, was that a problem?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Actually, we spoke more English at home because my grandmother was fluent in English. My step-grandfather didn't understand English, so we used Spanish for his benefit. But no, I don't recall it being a problem.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: It was more English-speaking than Spanish. It wasn't until we got married that we spoke more Spanish. I could see he was comfortable in both languages.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: By 1943, more Hispanics were here. In fact, a family from Grand Junction came to Marsing around 1940 or '41, my grandmother knew them. They're still here, dear friends. They later moved to Nampa.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: And that's when you started seeing more of them?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yes, at that time I started seeing more Hispanics in the area.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Do you remember any teachers or school situations that stood out?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yes, one. In third grade, I think I had a crush on her. Mrs. Gilmore, my teacher in Marsing. She went the extra mile to help me. She knew I needed more help than the other kids.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: She would take me by the hand and help me. That's what teaching was to me. I'm sure she knew I'd missed school and needed to catch up.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Tell her about when you wanted to play ball but couldn't.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: That was in junior high, seventh grade. I wanted to go out for basketball. They said, 'Everybody who wants to play, come on down.' I was one of the first.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: But to play, you had to furnish your own sneakers. I didn't have any, but I played barefoot the first day. The second day, I got blisters on the hardwood floor. My folks couldn't afford sneakers, so I didn't participate in basketball.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: And how did you feel about that?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I felt... I don't know, it's...

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Okay.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Our two boys are very athletic. I'm sure he knew more than he could show. When our boys were in state-champion basketball and football programs, he went out of his way to make sure they had what they needed, he was reliving what happened to him.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: In high school, our son lost pair after pair of sneakers, and he'd just go buy another pair.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I think I was trying to relive my childhood through my kids. I really wanted to play basketball, but I didn't want to burden my folks, they could barely make ends meet. So I said I didn't want to play anymore. I never participated in sports because you had to stay after school to practice, and that was when we worked in the fields.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Being a field worker, you had to work when crops were ready, the crops didn't wait for you. As the older male in the family, I was next in line to help support us. I liked school, but by 14, it became a hassle. There were social pressures, clubs, nice clothes, and I felt inadequate because I wasn't dressed properly.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: You felt out of place.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I felt out of place, not because I thought I wasn't adequate, but because I didn't have nice jeans, shoes, or shirts like the other kids. I knew something was wrong, but the kids didn't make me feel that way. I was my own worst critic. At 14, in ninth grade, I quit school.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Did you feel resentment? Did you blame anyone for not fitting in, because of peer pressure and not having what others had?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I didn't have resentment. I don't think the kids cared how I looked. I was my own worst critic. Some of those kids are still friends of mine today.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So he just didn't want to humiliate himself internally.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I told my grandmother, 'I don't want to go to school anymore.' She asked why, but I just didn't want to. I was 14. She didn't push too hard, she was caught between a rock and a hard place: if I went to school, less money came in; if I worked, more came in. She took the easy way out, and I was glad, because I didn't feel like I fit in socially.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: If it had been economically feasible, she would have insisted I stay in school.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: That still exists, children brought in to work because they're extra hands. Has that changed over the years?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yes, it's changed a bit. Not because kids have changed, but because we as parents want something better for our kids, and we know education is the only way. My grandmother would have insisted I go to school if she could have afforded it.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Did you have more education than your parents?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Oh, I'm sure I did. My father never went to school. When he came from Mexico, he didn't know English, he learned to read by reading newspapers. He still speaks a little English, enough to get by. My mother and grandmother spoke English fluently, they must have gone to school somewhere, but I don't know how far.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: You value education greatly. Earlier, you mentioned 'macho thinking' when you decided to quit school. What do you mean by that?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: To quit school.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What do you base that on?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I was the man of the house. I spoke Spanish and English. I did all the figuring in the fields, how many rows, how much per acre, per sack. I was the family bookkeeper. My grandmother saw me as more responsible, especially since my step-grandfather was an alcoholic. She needed someone to rely on, and I was chosen.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: We were more responsible.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: So you pretty much felt like the head of the...

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yeah. Right. Because, needless to say, and it's a sad thing to say, but my grandfather was the one that raised me, was also an alcoholic. And so. Needless to say that, you know, and I knew that my grandmother knew that. So she had somebody to she had to have somebody to rely on. And I guess I was the one that was chosen to do so.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: And so it it wasn't difficult for her for me to quit. I wouldn't say, you know, school wasn't really that difficult because I knew what was needed at home.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: By then, your real mother had died when you were ten. She'd remarried and had five more children, and died in childbirth. Your grandmother went and got all five and brought them to Marsing. When your grandmother died in 1945, you were 15, and became head of the household.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: When my mother died in April 1940, my sister and I were in Marsing with my grandmother and step-grandpa. We went back to Colorado for the funeral, and my grandmother brought back five half-siblings: Augustine, Rebecca, Alice, Chris, and Angelina (who died young). So she raised eight grandchildren total.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Yeah.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: His older sister married in 1947. That left them to raise each other, and he felt responsible. To this day, they look to him for guidance. When the youngest got married, he had to do the father's role, ask for the bride's hand.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: It sounds like your grandmother was the most influential.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Oh, yes, she was a very tough woman. How do you raise eight grandkids without modern conveniences? We heated water outside, carried it from a ditch to wash clothes and bathe. We hooked a water tank to a pickup to get drinking water.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: She must have been incredible. From what he says, she protected them like a mother.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Tell her about the time you came to Nampa for groceries and got accused.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: We came to Nampa to buy groceries, big shopping day. I was about 11 or 12. We went into a store, and soon the police came and accused my grandmother of stealing unpaid groceries.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: They couldn't arrest her.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: No, they took her to the police station. We had to prove we'd paid. We got our groceries back, but I don't recall an apology. I was young. Grandma always handled problems. I don't know if it was racial, we didn't know what racism was then.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: But if she hadn't spoken English...

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: She might have ended up in jail.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: But she was very outspoken, and fluent. She read them the riot act. My grandmother was domineering but protective. She taught us family was everything, take care of each other. We feared her more than anyone, she was the authority.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: After she died everything fell apart.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yes, my five half-siblings went with their father. My older brother joined the Navy. My sister married. It was just me, 15 years old, trying to hold things together.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: And you joined the migrant stream, going to Arizona. California for winter work.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yes, until I was drafted at 20 while working in a bakery in Calexico, California. I entered the service in 1951.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What do you recall about your service as a Mexican-American?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: There were other Hispanics, but I didn't notice discrimination. I wasn't looking for negatives. The service was a great experience, first time I had clean sheets, three square meals, two pairs of shoes, a clean uniform, showers, and a payday. It helped me grow up.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: He's very patriotic, believes in defending the country.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yes, I'm patriotic. The service helped me more than my streetwise youth ever did.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What do you mean by "streetwise"?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Drinking, smoking, fighting, things kids do without guidance. I did what I felt like, no one to tell me not to.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Any worst experiences from that time?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Once, I got drunk in Wilder and crashed into a divider on the way back to Nampa, I thought I'd killed myself. Another time, in Yuma, Arizona, we lived in a labor camp for two weeks with no money, sneaking in at night, covering ourselves with a mattress. We went to a dance in Somerton, and locals ran us out for being 'foreigners.'

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: We had nothing to eat but green grapefruit, breakfast, lunch, and supper.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: How long were you in the service?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Two years, 1951 to 1953. I served in Korea, never in direct combat, but we saw bodies in the river, men hanging from bridges, and once a Korean boy shot trying to enter our compound for food.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I enjoyed the service. I think every young person should spend two years in the military, it teaches responsibility.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: How many Hispanics were with you?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Very few, from Idaho, I was the only one drafted. But in the camps, there were more from other states.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: On economics, how does your situation compare to your parents'?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: We're better off, not because I worked harder, but because times changed. Each generation wants to do better for the next. My grandparents wanted that for me, even if they couldn't provide it.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What did you do after the service?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I worked in the fields one more year, then in 1953 my uncle got me a job at Idaho Concrete Pipe Company, digging ditches with a pick and shovel. I worked there until 1982.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: How did you meet your wife?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I promised God that if He let me live through Korea, I'd go to church first thing. In March 1953, still in uniform, I walked into church, and Martha sang a solo. We married in 1954, big traditional Mexican church wedding.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: She dreamed of him before they met.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: There were too many other girls, but he chose her.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Her father, a minister, didn’t approve at first.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: He wanted her to marry a preacher. But after we married, I became his favorite son-in-law.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: You later found your real father.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: At 30, my wife found a letter in my grandmother's attic, from my real father, Corsicana Vásquez. He’d written asking to see his children after my mother’s death, forgiving as Christ forgave. We’d been told he abandoned us, but the letter showed otherwise.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: We drove from San Diego to Monterey, my birthplace, searching phone books. By chance, we found Oak Street, and 659 Oak Street. I knocked, and met a small, bald man. I asked questions, he didn’t realize I was his son until his wife said, 'They’re your family!' He cried, hugged me, prayed. I slept like a baby that night, like I’d finally found him.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: He apologized for the past, I told him, 'You don’t owe me anything.' I promised to name my next son after him, if it was a boy. We did, Joséph. My father still lives in that same house in California. I talk to him often.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: You have strong faith.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Oh yes, we had a church upbringing.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What about Mexican customs and traditions?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I love mariachi music, rice and beans, tortillas, but I don’t like chili. As a kid, we didn’t celebrate Cinco de Mayo. I’m proud to be Mexican, but I was raised among white kids, so culture wasn’t emphasized. I didn’t push it on my kids, they speak English, have good jobs. Maybe they’ll explore their heritage later.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What about language?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I wish I’d insisted they speak Spanish. Today, bilingualism is valuable. But back then, survival meant speaking English, going to school, fitting in.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Did you experience prejudice?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Not as a kid, I didn’t know what to look for. Later, when promoted to purchasing manager at Idaho Concrete, some resented me, especially after they fired a college graduate to give me the job. My boss warned me, but I figured it was jealousy, not racism.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Did you ever get your diploma?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Yes, at 55. When the company folded in 1982, I was 52 and unemployed. I applied at the courthouse and became a deputy, but couldn’t go to the police academy without a diploma. So I got my GED in two and a half months for $20. Graduating made me feel ten feet tall.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: At 55, I entered the police academy. It was hard, learning and physical, but my goal was just to finish. They treated me gently because of my age, but I graduated. Now, at 60, I’m running for Canyon County Commissioner, as a Republican. I love Idaho. This is my home.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Do you define yourself as Mexicano?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: I can’t help it.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Are you proud of what you are?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Oh, yeah. I’m proud to be Hispanic, and American. My kids married gringos and a Guatemalan, life doesn’t go as planned. But family is everything. If I died today, I’d say I accomplished what I set out to do, not as a millionaire, but as a man with family who loves him.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: What do you think of the Hispanic Commission’s interviews?

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: We need to promote the positive in our community, not just gangs and negativity. We have a lot to offer. As Kennedy said: 'Ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country.' I hope when I’m laid to rest, they’ll say, 'He did a little bit.' Sometimes a little becomes a lot.

speaker: Martha Tórrez
words: Thank you on behalf of the Idaho Humanities Council I'd like to thank you both for your time.

speaker: Abel Vásquez
words: Thank you very much.
